query: What actions can be taken to increase soil organic matter on agricultural land?
relevant_summary: Evidence from action documents indicates multiple practices associated with increases in soil organic matter or soil organic carbon on agricultural land: Including legumes or forage in crop rotations increased soil organic matter and soil organic carbon in several studies, though a few reported mixed or lower effects (857). Growing cover crops as living mulches or between rows increased soil organic matter in two controlled trials, with one trial finding no effect (897). Growing cover crops in fallow periods improved soil structure and nutrient retention, with studies reporting increased soil carbon and, in several trials, increased nitrogen and carbon under cover crops, although some European studies found no marked effect on soil organic matter (898). Applying manures and agricultural composts increased soil organic carbon in multiple studies and increased soil organic matter in one controlled, randomized, replicated study, while some studies found no effect on organic matter (911). Applying composts (not otherwise specified) at high rates increased soil organic matter and microbial biomass in a controlled, randomized, replicated trial (889). Incorporating fresh plant material or crop remains (e.g., straw) increased soil organic carbon across multiple studies and, in some cases, improved aggregation and reduced nitrate leaching (910). Retaining crop residues increased soil organic carbon and nitrogen in two randomized, replicated trials (907). Reduced tillage increased soil organic matter relative to conventional tillage in multiple replicated studies and a meta-analysis, though some studies found similar levels (1371). No-tillage increased soil organic matter relative to tilled soils in many replicated studies and a meta-analysis, with some studies finding mixed or similar results (1369). Changing tillage practices toward reduced or no-till increased soil organic carbon across numerous studies and often maintained or increased soil organic matter and improved soil structure, though results varied by context (906).

query: Which actions are most beneficial for increasing the diversity of soil organisms?
relevant_summary: Evidence linking actions to increased diversity or abundance of soil organisms includes: reducing fertilizer, pesticide or herbicide use, which was associated with higher diversity of soil invertebrates and microorganisms in low-input systems (904); growing cover crops when fields are empty, which resulted in more diverse nematode communities and, in one trial, greater microbial biomass under ryegrass than a ryegrass/vetch mix (898); using cover crops or ground cover in perennial crops, which increased microbial biomass in multiple studies, increased bacteria in one study, and increased nematode numbers in one comparison (2304); growing cover crops beneath the main crop or between rows (living mulches), which increased bacterial numbers and activity (897); no tillage as the main cultivation method, which often increased microbial biomass and increased earthworm numbers in two studies, with some studies reporting different nematode and mite communities (2306); reduced tillage, which frequently increased microbial biomass, increased denitrifying bacteria in one study, and increased earthworms in one of three comparisons (2307); establishing grass buffer strips, which increased microbial biomass in one study (2308); excluding grazers, which increased nematode numbers and nematode community diversity on a streambank (2309); amending soil with composts, which increased microbial biomass in one trial (889). Controlled traffic showed mixed results for microbial metrics: one study found higher numbers and bacterial activity under controlled traffic, while another found higher microbial biomass when traffic was not controlled (899). Adding sewage sludge did not change microbial biomass in two studies (2303).

- Amend soil with non-chemical minerals and mineral wastes: replicated studies found reduced nutrient loss and, in one case, reduced erosion after mineral additions [892].
- Plant new hedges/hedgerows: replicated studies found hedgerows reduced soil erosion and increased soil organic matter [744].
